question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
The average value of a function \(f(x)\) over an interval \([a,b]\) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{b-a}\int_a^b f(x)\, dx\end{aligned}\]

In this case, this is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2}\int_0^2 xe^x\, dx\end{aligned}\]

Let us then compute the indefinite integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int xe^x\, dx\end{aligned}\]

which we can compute via integration by parts. If we let \(u = x\) and \(dv = e^xdx\), then we find that

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{matrix} u = x & v = e^x \\ du = dx & dv = e^xdx\end{matrix}\end{aligned}\]

and so it follows that

\[\begin{aligned} \int x e^x dx = xe^x - \int e^x dx = xe^x - e^x + C= (x - 1)e^x + C\end{aligned}\]

If we then put that into the definition of the average value, we find that the average value is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2}\int_0^2 xe^x\, dx = \frac{1}{2}(x - 1)e^x|_0^2 = \frac{1}{2}\big((2 - 1)e^2 - (0 - 1)e^0\big) = \frac{1}{2}(e^2 + 1)\end{aligned}\]
